Title: A Ramanujan sum involving $\sinh$
Content:
Today, in a personal communication, I was asked to prove the classical result
$$\boxed{ \sum_{n\geq 1}\frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{n^3\sinh(\pi n)} = \frac{\pi^3}{360}}\tag{CR} $$
which I believe is due to Ramanujan. My proof can be found here and it is based on the closed form for $\sum_{n\geq 1}\frac{1}{m^2+n^2}$ and double counting. I would use this question for collecting alternative proofs . I am already aware that standard techniques for tackling series with a similar structure are The Poisson summation formula ; The residue theorem coupled with the Laplace transform of $\text{Li}_k$ (I used this approach due to Simon Plouffe here , for instance); Eisenstein series related to Gaussian integers; Identities involving Dirichlet's series, since $$r_2(N)=\left|\{(a,b)\in\mathbb{Z}^2:a^2+b^2=N\}\right|=4 \sum_{d\mid N}\chi_4(d)$$
(this can be regarded as an analytic-combinatorial equivalent of the statement " $\mathbb{Z}[i]$ is a UFD "). I also know that a cornerstone is given by Zucker's The Summation of Series of Hyperbolic Functions , 1979. Let us see if we can devise a very short proof of $(\text{CR})$ through these ingredients or other ones.
